Besides the above frameworks for aggregating the IPCC’s three components individually, the vulnerability
assessments have been also conducted by several modified frameworks that use various combinations of two of
the IPCC’s three components. Based on the basic concept addressed in the IPCC TAR
another framework that uses the potential impact component by combining the exposure and sensitivity compo-
nents. For assessing the relative vulnerability of communities to climate change impacts, Hahn
a framework for the livelihood vulnerability index, where a function of the exposure and coping components is
combined with the sensitivity component. In the MOVE (Method for the Improvement of Vulnerability in Europe)
framework, the average of the sensitivity and coping components is combined with the exposure component as
On behalf of the three modified frameworks where the two components are combined to be
compiled with the other component, the framework using the potential impact
exposure and sensitivity is selected for one of the conventional frameworks for the vulnerability indicator. Thus,

) are representative variants of additive and multiplicative aggregations
for the IPCC’s three components, but some of the variants, not to be covered here, may employ a mixed aggrega-
tion scheme of additive and multiplicative forms, such as the MOVE framework.
, the vulnerability to climate change has usually been estimated using one of the six
gations. Therefore, the influence of the six multi-attribute utility forms required for a composite indicator on
measuring vulnerability is comprehensively examined as follows.
Summary of the conventional aggregation frameworks in general forms and equal-weighed forms for
